prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: We request observations in Band 7 in the most extended configuration withone pointing (FOV=18arcsec) per galaxy. Band 7 comprises multiple chemical diagnostic lines of the ISM and provides the best match in spatial resolution to our HST images, which is sufficient to resolve the gas distribution and kinematics in the cusp at a spatial resolution of 0.13arcsec (~50pc). Our sensitivity requirement is driven by our primary goal to map the CO distribution and kinematics (at 5km/s) in detail for a representative sample of 5 cusp and 5 core galaxies. We have estimated the CO J=3-2 line emission either from previous total CO J=3-2 line flux measurements from the SMA (NGC~1614, Wilson et al. 2008) or from total CO J=1-0 line flux observations (Baan et al. 2008) using an average conversion factor quoted for LIRGs of CO (3-2)/CO(1-0)=4 (Iono et al. 2009, Leech et al. 2010, Wilson et al. 2008) and linewidths of ~200-300km/s (e.g. Wilson et al. 2008). For two LIRGs, ARP256 and ESO550-IG025, no CO measurements were available in the literature and we applied the far-IR luminosity to CO J=2-3 flux density conversion (log[L_Co3-2]=-.4+0.7*log[L_FIR], Yao et al.2003) and as shown in Baan et al. 2008 (CO 1-0 >10^19Jy km/s pc^2 for log[FIR]>11.0). The line flux per resolution element depends on the spatial size of the emission region. We assume that most of the CO emission originates from the central 2 arcsec for our galaxies (~800pc) and we divide the total flux by a factor of 200. The requires sensitivity range is (1.5-2.5) mJy (at 5km/s spectral binning) which results in signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 8-30 in the CO emission line per resolution element. For the HCO+ (4-3) line emission we are only interested in the integrated flux emission which corresponds to a spectral binning of (50-100)km/s and results in a sensitivity of 0.3-0.8 mJy. Previous observations of starburst and infrared luminous galaxies revealed a HCO+(4-3)/CO(3-2) ratio of 0.1 (Wilson et al. 2008, Baan et al. 2008, Costagliola et al. 2011), which results in typical SNR of 4-20 for our sources. Given that the emission regions are likely more concentrated, we expect to achieve larger SNRs.
Imaging requirements: The FOV of ~18arcsec and the maximum angular scale of 2.5arcsec will cover the spatial sizes of the cusps (100-500pc, 0.35-2arcsec) and its surrounding of the central disk of our galaxies (see Fig.~1). We have verified that we will obtain enough uv-coverage and dynamic range for imaging the nuclear distribution of the dust and gas with the ALMA simulator based on our HST NIR and optical images for the extended configuration. All of our sources are single nuclei galaxies with no complicated structure and we were able to easily reproduce the nuclear morphology using on-source times of 10~mins.
Correlator setup: One spectral window is centered on the keyline of our study, namely the spectral line transitions of CO (J=3-2) while the other spectral windows cover HCO+ (J=4-3), CH3OH (J=4-3), and SiO (J=8-7) in dual polarization with one spectral window (containing the most narrow emission line) designated for dust continuum observation at 880 micro~m. The bandwidth of the spectral windows is 1875MHz (1600km/s to fully cover the base of the CO, HCO+ and CH3OH line (including the dust continuum). The central frequency of the SiO spectral window is in some cases shifted to fit into the sideband, but still covers the central emission frequency of SiO (J=8-7). The channels will be binned in the data reduction process to obtain a spectral resolution of 5~km/s for CO and 50-100~km/s for our secondary lines. The CO emission line will be sufficient for analyzing the kinematic features (rotation, spin parameter, dispersion, shock disturbances, outflows) of the COemission line which is expected to have alinewidth of ~200-300km/s (CO 3-2, Wilson et al. 2008).
Same spectral setup and imaging requirements as for NGC1614

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose observations with ALMA to spectroscopically map the molecular gas and dust that is associated with the build up of nuclear cusps in late merger stages of Luminous Infrared Galaxies (LIRGs). Our Hubble Space Telescope (HST) near-IR imaging program of the GOALS survey has recently spatially resolved the nuclear stellar structure in 88 LIRGs and revealed an increasing fraction of strong cusps towards late merger stages. ALMA will spatially resolve the morphology of the gas components of the cusp on a scale comparable to that of the HST. We have selected the five strongest cusp galaxies in our sample and a well matched comparison sample of five pre-cusp galaxies. The aim of this proposal is to unveil the molecular gas morphology (CO) and mechanisms associated with cusp formation and to accurately measure how much gas mass is involved in the build-up of stellar cusps. The decomposition of the gas kinematics will provide an unprecedented spatial measurement of the mass-to-light ratio of nuclear cusps and cores, providing a crucial test whether the central dark matter distribution is affected by the cusp/core evolution as seen in the stellar component or not.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy and Space Science, Australia Telescope National Facility
